intro: Uleiorchis, commonly known as the ghost orchid, is a rare and elusive flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Orchidaceae family and is characterized by its lack of leaves, relying instead on its roots for photosynthesis. The plant produces delicate, white or greenish-white flowers that bloom during the summer months. Uleiorchis thrives in specific habitats, such as wetlands and pine rocklands, where it forms symbiotic relationships with mycorrhizal fungi. Due to habitat loss and environmental changes, it is considered endangered and is protected in many regions.
